ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I received incredibly practical knowledge in professional business Chinese alongside a nuanced understanding of the transnational companies operating in China + China's economic expansion abroad
I learned a lot about China/businesses, how to speak more formally in Chinese, and general language improvement (especially vocabulary-wise)
Chinese vocabulary and grammar related to business, such as economy and GDP, foreign brands entering China, market shares and target audiences, etc.
Terms used in business Chinese/related to the economy and the success and failures of International companies who entered China (through specific case studies)

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Everything was great, especially the supplementary readings and lessons. I understand there is more focus on Chinese companies in China in the second half of the course, but since most students only take one semester, it would have been nice to learn more about "chinese" companies in china and abroad.

Strengths: learn about a lot of very interesting and relevant topics! and Chen Laoshi is very kind and cares about individual growth. You don't have to memorize how to write everything - there is only a short content quiz and dictation that she posts ahead of time for each unit. 
Weaknesses: Hard to work within a classroom with a huge range of Chinese levels. We had non-native speakers to native speakers where Mandarin is their first language. Ended up that for most supplemental articles that covered more difficult vocab and topics, native/more fluent speakers would participate more.

Strength: Genuinely interesting context (from learning about KFC and Starbucks to IKEA and P&G), as well as Chen Laoshi herselfwho always tries to make class engaging and fun for all of us. No weaknesses I can think of at the moment.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, any student interesting in taking their Chinese to the professional level should take this class!
Yes!!! The professor is so amazing and the course is very well (and reasonably) structured. Anyone interested in Chinese should take this course.
I would recommend because of the topics/vocab you learn and to have a class with Chen Laoshi. But would just warn that there will probably be native speakers who speak extremely fast and fluently.
Absolutely! Such a fascinating course whether you plan to go into business or not. The topics are not only interesting but also taught exceptionally well by Chen Laoshi.
